supercontext.mission: Create a single reference document that lists all active orders with statuses, priorities, and quick access links.

goal: Build a local index (README/table) under `docs/orders/` summarizing every order file, their priorities, current status, and owners, so future tasks are easy to discover without browsing JSON files individually.
execution_instructions: Read existing orders under `docs/orders/` and categorize them (active vs completed).
Do not change the orders themselves in this task; focus on organizing them in an index.
Keep the index in Markdown so it renders cleanly on GitHub and in editors.

tasks.description: Collect metadata for each order file.
steps: List all `*.json` and `*.md` order files under `docs/orders/`.
Extract key fields: `order_id`, `priority`, `version`, and note if an order is completed (look for `-COMPLETED.md`).
Capture optional fields such as goal or brief description for quick context.
Add or update `docs/orders/README.md` to include a table of orders with columns: Order ID, Priority, Version, Status, Description (one-liner), Link.
Group orders by status (e.g., Active, Completed, Planning) to make triage easier.
Include a short usage note at the top explaining how to add new entries when orders are created or completed.
For completed orders that already have `-COMPLETED.md`, link the index entry to both the original order and completion notes.
If any order is clearly obsolete, flag it in the index with a note (do not delete in this task).
Add a reminder in the index about updating this README whenever future orders are added or finished.

acceptance_criteria: `docs/orders/README.md` lists every order with clear status/priority info.
Each entry links to the order JSON (and completion note if present).
The README includes brief instructions for maintaining the index going forward.
No changes are made to the order JSON files themselves in this task.

what_not_to_do: Do not modify order JSON contents (titles, steps, etc.).
Do not remove or archive orders in this order.
Avoid external tooling—keep everything in Markdown within the repo.
constraints.escalation_guidance: If an order’s status is unclear, flag it in the README (e.g., 'Status: Needs review') instead of guessing.

testing.notes: No automated tests required; verify readability by opening the README in a Markdown viewer.
